summary: William H. Cross was an employee of the U.S. House of Representatives Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). He is mentioned in several payroll and certification reports spanning from October 1977 to November 1978. These documents list his name, position, and salary during that period. The documents suggest he was a staff member of the HSCA during its investigation into the JFK assassination.
significance: William H. Cross's significance lies in his employment with the HSCA, the committee tasked with reinvestigating the JFK assassination. While the documents do not specify his exact role, his presence on the payroll indicates he contributed to the committee's work during a crucial period of its investigation.
